title: Even the pacifist message that many readers see in the play is predominantly negative. Both Adrastus (949–52) and the herald (481–85) attribute pacifism to the fear of death, while Aithra sees hēsukhia (inactivity) as the shameful inverse of the ponoi (labors) through which the polis thrives and grows (323–25). The contrast between hēsukhia and ponos resonates strongly
with Athenian imperialist discourse
